article.title: First-Principles Simulations of Warm Dense Lithium Fluoride

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the PIMC/DFT-MD shock Hugoniot curves with several EOS tables and models. What characteristic of the PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio models allows them to accurately predict the shoulder and compression maximum along the Hugoniot curve, unlike SESAME and LEOS?
choices: Treatment of electrons as a non-uniform electron gas
Explicit treatment of quantum-mechanical shell structure
Use of the Thomas-Fermi model
Reliance on experimental data at high temperatures and pressures

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows a zoomed-in view of the PIMC/DFT-MD shock Hugoniot curve near the experimental data.  What trend is observed as the initial density used in the Hugoniot calculation is increased?
choices: The compression maximum shifts to lower densities.
The compression maximum becomes more pronounced.
The overall compression ratio slightly decreases.
The curve becomes less smooth, with more pronounced features.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure focuses on the compression maximum region of the PIMC/DFT-MD shock Hugoniot curve. What physical phenomenon is attributed to this compression maximum?
choices: Dissociation of LiF molecules
Excitation of lattice vibrations
K-shell ionization of lithium and fluorine ions
L-shell ionization of lithium and fluorine ions

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays the temperature-pressure conditions for PIMC and DFT-MD calculations along different isochores. What is the purpose of the blue, dash-dotted line representing the Hugoniot curve in this context?
choices: To indicate the phase boundary between solid and liquid LiF
To show the locus of final states attainable through shock compression
To separate regions where PIMC and DFT-MD simulations are valid
To illustrate the temperature dependence of the LiF band gap

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the LiF excess pressure calculated by PIMC, DFT-MD, and the Debye-H端ckel model at different densities. What is the primary reason for the Debye-H端ckel model becoming inadequate at lower temperatures (T < 5x10^6 K)?
choices: It neglects electron degeneracy effects.
It assumes a fully ionized plasma.
It fails to account for bound electronic states.
It does not account for the finite size of ions.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the LiF excess internal energy relative to the ideal Fermi gas, as calculated by PIMC, DFT-MD, and the Debye-H端ckel model. What do the overlapping results between PIMC and DFT-MD at T = 1x10^6 K indicate?
choices: The system is accurately described as a classical plasma at this temperature.
The use of free-particle nodes in PIMC becomes invalid at this temperature.
Zero-temperature exchange-correlation functionals are valid for WDM applications at this temperature.
The fermion sign problem in PIMC becomes significant at this temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the PIMC/DFT-MD shock Hugoniot curves with other models and experimental data in T-p/po space.  What key difference in the treatment of electrons leads to the SESAME and LEOS models not exhibiting any compression maximum, unlike PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio?
choices: SESAME and LEOS use average-atom potentials, while PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio use all-electron calculations.
SESAME and LEOS neglect quantum-mechanical shell structure, while PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio account for it.
SESAME and LEOS are based on classical molecular dynamics, while PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio are based on quantum mechanics.
SESAME and LEOS assume a constant ionization state, while PIMC/DFT-MD and Purgatorio allow for dynamic ionization.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure focuses on the compression maximum region of the PIMC/DFT-MD shock Hugoniot curve. Which ionization process is primarily responsible for this feature?
choices: L-shell ionization of lithium
K-shell ionization of lithium
L-shell ionization of fluorine
K-shell ionization of fluorine

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares shock Hugoniot curves for various materials. What general trend is observed in the maximum compression ratio achieved as the atomic number (Z) of the material increases?
choices: The maximum compression ratio increases.
The maximum compression ratio decreases.
The maximum compression ratio remains constant.
There is no clear trend between atomic number and maximum compression ratio.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents pair-correlation functions for Li-Li, Li-F, and F-F pairs in LiF liquid at different densities. What do the relatively featureless Li-Li curves compared to the other g(r) functions indicate?
choices: Lithium atoms are strongly bound to fluorine atoms.
Lithium atoms experience weaker interactions compared to fluorine atoms.
Lithium atoms diffuse slower than fluorine atoms.
Lithium atoms are less ionized than fluorine atoms.

multiple_choice_question.text: These figures illustrate ion-ion pair-correlation functions for Li-Li, Li-F, and F-F pairs in LiF plasma at different temperatures and densities. What is the primary driver of the observed decrease in correlation between ions as temperature increases?
choices: Increased nuclear quantum effects
Weakening of the ionic Coulomb repulsion
Increase in thermal ionization
Decrease in pressure ionization

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares pair-correlation functions calculated using PIMC and DFT-MD at the same temperature and density. What is the significance of the near-perfect overlap between the curves?
choices: It validates the use of free-particle nodes in PIMC simulations.
It demonstrates the consistency of both methods in predicting plasma structure.
It indicates that LiF behaves as a classical plasma at this temperature and density.
It confirms the accuracy of the Debye-H端ckel model for LiF under these conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: These figures display the number of electrons within a sphere of radius r around Li and F nuclei, respectively. What can be concluded from the decreasing trend in N(r) for fluorine with increasing temperature?
choices: The fluorine ion is undergoing pressure ionization.
The fluorine K-shell is becoming increasingly ionized.
The electron density around the fluorine nucleus is decreasing due to thermal expansion.
The fluorine ion is forming covalent bonds with neighboring lithium ions.

multiple_choice_question.text: These figures present electron-electron pair correlation functions for opposite and parallel spins, respectively. What causes the strong repulsion between electrons at short distances observed in Figure 15?
choices: Coulomb repulsion
Pauli exclusion principle
Electron exchange interactions
Nuclear screening effects

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays electronic density of states (DOS) along the principal shock Hugoniot curve. What is the primary factor responsible for the broadening and merging of DOS peaks at higher temperature-density conditions?
choices: Formation of a metallic state
Increased electron-phonon interactions
Thermal excitation of electrons
Ionization of lithium and fluorine atoms

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows electronic DOS at different densities for a fixed temperature in the liquid regime. What is the reason for the formation of a band gap at increasingly higher temperatures with increasing density?
choices: Increased electron degeneracy pressure
Stronger ionic Coulomb interactions leading to structural ordering
Suppression of thermal ionization
Formation of bound excitons
